author: samwilsn
content:
Notes from today's architecture call:

 - Added a bunch of stuff to https://hackmd.io/@SamWilsn/ByYJvijJs
 - Want to treat TTD as a fake "Retroactive Fork" where we pretend to remove all TTD code and instead hard code the merge block. I think <@425279588009246720> and <@552133098075193354> might have some thoughts on this.

author: timbeiko
content: I think, if possible, using TTD over the block is better, but very very weak opinion

author: timbeiko
content: Just because the TTD is the actual trigger and the EL block is more of an "artifact" of the TTD

author: timbeiko
content: So it's mostly an aesthetic preference/nitpick: if EELS is much easier to build around a block then I wouldn't spend a ton of effort trying to make TTD work

author: sky.cactus
content: I suspect it adds a lot of complexity to consensus code to retain all of the transition logic that will never execute again.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are other instances where the execution spec has removed code that used to be part of consensus but was never actually called, this feels like another one of those things that allows us to clean up the specification notably.

author: sky.cactus
content: Any new client being written can just have a hard fork block number and they will be able to sync just fine.

author: samwilsn
content:
Yep, exactly our thoughts. It isn't trivial to add to the specs.

That's why I'm calling it a retroactive fork, like limiting account nonces.

author: samwilsn
content: Sure, you needed it at one point in time, but it's unnecessary now.
